title: Using the Slides
text:
The keyboard shortcuts available while viewing the slides are provided below. These can also be seen by pressing ?.



Key
Action




CTRL + SHIFT + F
Search


→, ↓, SPACE, N, L, J
Next slide


← , ↑ , P , H , K
Previous Slide


Alt + ←/↑/→/↓
Navigate without transitions


Shift + ←/↑/→/↓
Jump to first/last slide


B, ,, .
Pause


F
Fullscreen


ESC, O
Slide overview


E
PDF export mode


M
Toggle menu


S
Speaker notes view



The slides will also be available as PDFs on bCourses.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:

2 PM - 3 PM and 3 PM - 4 PM in Cory 289

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Expectations
This is a 1 unit class.


Weekly Lab (13 total)
Monthly Quiz (3 total)
Biweekly – every 2 weeks – Homework (6 total)
Final Exam

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Our Lab
Here’s the tentative structure for our labs.


For the first 15-20 minutes, I’ll lecture briefly on select topics from the week’s material.
Afterwards, you are free to work on the lab, and I’m available to help.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Installing R and RStudio
Please install R and RStudio now if you haven’t already.

R: https://www.r-project.org/
RStudio: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/

Let me know if you have technical difficulties.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
RStudio Demo
Separate window.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
RMarkdown
RMarkdown (.rmd) is file type that allows us to merge,

Formatted written material,
and R code

into a single document.


This presentation is using a variant of RMarkdown!

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
This is RMarkdown?


## RMarkdown

RMarkdown (``.rmd``) is file type that allows us to merge,

-   Formatted written material,
-   and **R** code

into a single document.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text: RMarkdown - Basic Formatting Software like Microsoft Word and Google Docs hides the underlying format representation. In a markup language, we embed the formatting alongside the text. An Example: HTML (HyperText Markup Language) This is bold! But this is merely emphasized! Another Example: LaTeX This is \textbf{bold!} But this is merely \textit{emphasized!} RMarkdown This is **bold!** But this is merely _emphasized_!

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Headers
Aren’t headers…
… just lovely?


## Headers

### Aren't headers...

#### ... just lovely?



\(N\) # characters denotes an \(Nth\) level header.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Font Face: Bold
I’m bold and uncontrolled!


## Font Face: **Bold**

I'm **bold** and **uncontrolled!**



Surrounding text with ** at each end makes it bold.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Font Face: Italics
Don’t eat that burger! Don’t eat that burger!


## Font Face: _Italics_

Don't eat _that_ burger! Don't _eat_ that burger!



Surrounding text with _ at each end italicizes it.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
section: Font Face: Plain Text or Code
text:
Font Face: Plain Text or Code
The variable x passed into function main.


## Font Face: ``Plain Text or Code``

The variable ``x`` passed into function ``main``.



Surrounding text with `` at each end makes it plain text (like code).

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
And more…
We can also embed lists, tables, images, and many other components!

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Code Chunks
We include code in what we call code chunks. A basic example in this document:


print("Hello, World!")

[1] "Hello, World!"

x <- 3
y <- 5
print(paste("x + y =", x + y))

[1] "x + y = 8"





Note that we’ve included the output of our code directly in the document.

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Code Chunk: Plot Example


plot(1:10, seq(10, 100, 10), type = "l", 
     xlab = "Time Spent Studying (Hours)", 
     ylab = "Quiz Grade (%)")

title: Lab 01: Setup, RMarkdown
text:
Knitting
Going from the plain text format to a presentation format (.pdf, .html) is called knitting the document.
